name: 2017_10_humanities_student_major_1998_uoft
title: 2017-10-humanities-student-major_1998_UofT.txt
content_scrubbed:
As someone who wants to continue education after uni where a competitive, high GPA is important, it[.] just crushing to see anything below an 80

I don't know what program you are in but I averaged mid-high 70s and attended a very classy university for my humanities MA. (Then I came back to U of T, haha). 

(ik UofT has it[.] bullshit ~C average in first year, but the average isn't my concern

It should be. If you're above average in your classes, you're above average. If you're at average, you're at average.

I am a PhD student and the students in my program had a massive variety of undergraduate experiences. Some aced their degrees, others did very poorly. We all ended up in the same program. There are multiple ways to get where you want to go other than the straight line, and you'll find as you go through life that the majority of the group did take an unconventional route. 

Your more than 2h commute is not good. Consider moving to a closer location. 

Do you even have enough time to get enough sleep, have a good social life, get a high GPA and leave some room for hobbies?

That[.] a lot to try for. I would shoot for good GPA, some socialising, a hobby and reasonable sleep. Sleep, especially. Sleeping is incredibly important to successful studying.
